title: Adobong Baboy
subtitle: Pork adobo braised in soy and vinegar
instructions: Heat oil; sauté garlic and onion.
Add pork; cook until lightly browned.
Pour soy sauce and vinegar (do not stir 30 seconds). Add peppercorns, bay leaves, and water.
Cover and simmer until tender, 30–40 minutes.
Uncover and reduce sauce; balance with a pinch of sugar. Adjust seasoning.
Serve with rice.
description: Classic pork adobo braised in soy, vinegar, and garlic.

title: Adobong Dilaw
subtitle: Batangas-style turmeric pork adobo
ingredients: 1 tsp ground turmeric (or 1 tbsp fresh grated)
instructions: Sauté garlic and onion in oil.
Add pork; cook until browned.
Pour vinegar and water; add turmeric, peppercorns, and bay leaves.
Simmer until pork is tender and sauce reduces.
Season with salt.
description: Batangas-style yellow adobo colored and scented with turmeric.

title: Adobong Gulay
subtitle: Vegetable adobo
instructions: Heat oil in a pan, sauté garlic and onions.
Add potatoes and cook for 5 minutes.
Add eggplant and carrots, stir-fry for 5 minutes.
Pour soy sauce and vinegar, add bay leaves.
Cover and simmer for 10 minutes until vegetables are tender.
Season with salt and pepper.
Let sauce reduce slightly before serving.
Serve hot with steamed rice.
description: A vegetarian version of the classic adobo, featuring mixed vegetables braised in the traditional soy sauce and vinegar combination.

title: Adobong Kangkong
subtitle: Water spinach in garlicky adobo sauce
instructions: Sauté garlic and onion in oil.
Add kangkong stems; cook 1–2 minutes, then leaves.
Splash in soy and vinegar; season with pepper and sugar. Toss just until wilted.
description: Quick garlicky adobo-style sauté of water spinach.

title: Adobong Manok
subtitle: Traditional Filipino chicken adobo
instructions: Sauté garlic, onion, and ginger until fragrant.
Add chicken and cook until browned.
Add soy sauce and vinegar, bring to boil.
Add bay leaves and simmer for 30 minutes.
Season with salt and pepper to taste.
Serve hot with steamed rice.
description: A traditional Filipino version of the classic adobong manok, featuring authentic flavors and cooking techniques passed down through generations.

title: Adobong Pusit
subtitle: Squid cooked in its ink with soy and vinegar
instructions: Sauté garlic and onion in oil.
Add squid; cook 1–2 minutes.
Pour soy, vinegar, sugar, and ink; add bay leaf and pepper.
Simmer 3–5 minutes only (do not overcook).
description: Tender squid in a savory-tangy black adobo sauce.

title: Adobong Sitaw
subtitle: String beans simmered in soy-vinegar adobo
instructions: Sauté garlic, onion, and tomatoes.
Add sitaw; toss 1 minute.
Pour soy and vinegar; cover and cook until crisp-tender.
Season to taste.
description: String beans in a light soy-vinegar sauté.

title: Adobong Talong
subtitle: Eggplant braised in soy-vinegar garlic sauce
instructions: Pan-fry eggplant pieces in 2 tbsp oil until lightly browned; set aside.
In same pan, add 1 tbsp oil; sauté garlic and onion.
Return eggplant; add soy, vinegar, sugar, and pepper. Toss 1–2 minutes.
description: Eggplant briefly pan-fried then tossed in garlicky adobo glaze.

title: Afritadang Baboy
subtitle: Pork afritada in tomato sauce with potatoes and carrots
instructions: Sauté aromatics; add meat and brown.
Add tomato sauce and broth; simmer until tender.
Add potatoes, carrots, bell pepper; season and finish.
description: Tomato-based stew with potatoes and carrots.

title: Afritadang Manok
subtitle: Chicken afritada stewed in tomato sauce
instructions: Sauté aromatics; add meat and brown.
Add tomato sauce and broth; simmer until tender.
Add potatoes, carrots, bell pepper; season and finish.
description: Tomato-based stew with potatoes and carrots.

title: Arroz Caldo
subtitle: Filipino chicken rice porridge
instructions: Heat oil in a pot, sauté garlic, onion, and ginger.
Add chicken and cook until lightly browned.
Add rice and stir for 2 minutes.
Pour in chicken broth and simmer until rice is soft.
Season with salt and pepper.
Serve hot with calamansi and boiled egg on top.
description: A comforting rice porridge infused with ginger and chicken, perfect for rainy days.

title: Arroz Valenciana
subtitle: Fiesta rice with chicken, chorizo, and aromatics
instructions: Sauté garlic and onion in annatto oil. Add chicken and chorizo; brown lightly.
Stir in rinsed rice; toast 1–2 minutes.
Pour broth (and coconut milk if using); add turmeric/annatto; cover and cook on low, stirring occasionally.
Add carrots and bell pepper in the last 10 minutes. Cook until rice is tender and liquid is absorbed.
Rest 5 minutes before serving.
description: Fiesta rice similar to paella with Filipino flavors.

title: Asado de Carajay
subtitle: One of the food served during the Liberation of Bulacan Province
ingredients: 4 pcs ginger (chopped and squeeze to get juice)
12–16 cloves garlic, finely chopped (about ¼ cup)
½ cup red onion, finely chopped
½ cup white onion, finely chopped
instructions: Rub onto the chicken a handful of salt and the ginger's juice.
Marinate the chicken for at least 1 hour in soysauce, dayap juice and laurel leaves, then fry a little, set aside.
Sauté garlic, white onion and red onion, add the liquid marinade and let it simmer.
Put the chicken unto the mixture, add beer and additional laurel leaves if desired.
Season it with salt and sugar (according to taste).
Cook in low heat until the chicken is tender and cooked and the sauce thickens.
description: A traditional Bulacan heritage chicken dish served during the Liberation of Bulacan Province, marinated and cooked in a savory sauce.

title: Baka Pares
subtitle: Beef in sweet-savory sauce served with garlic rice
instructions: Sauté garlic and onion; add beef and ginger; cook until lightly browned.
Pour soy sauce, sugar, and water/broth; add star anise. Simmer on low until beef is tender (60–90 minutes).
Adjust seasoning with salt and pepper. Garnish with spring onions; serve with garlic rice and soup.
description: Sweet-savory braised beef served with garlic rice and clear soup.

title: Baked Macaroni
subtitle: Filipino-style baked macaroni with sweet meat sauce
ingredients: 2 cups tomato sauce (+ 2 tbsp banana ketchup, optional)
instructions: Make meat sauce: sauté garlic/onion; brown ground meat. Add tomato sauce and water; season; simmer 10–15 minutes (add carrot if using).
Make béchamel: melt butter; whisk in flour; cook 1 minute. Slowly add milk; thicken; stir in cheese; season lightly.
Combine pasta with meat sauce. Transfer to baking dish; spread béchamel; top with more cheese if desired.
Bake at 180°C (350°F) for 15–25 minutes until bubbly and lightly golden. Rest 5 minutes.
description: Filipino-style baked macaroni with sweet-savory meat sauce and creamy cheese topping.

title: Bicol Express
subtitle: Spicy pork in coconut milk and chilies
ingredients: 4–6 long green chilies (sliced) + bird’s eye chilies to taste
instructions: Sauté garlic and onion; add pork; cook until lightly browned and fat renders.
Stir in shrimp paste; cook 1 minute.
Pour coconut milk; add chilies; simmer until pork is tender and sauce reduces.
Add coconut cream (if using) and simmer to desired thickness. Season to taste.
description: Spicy pork stewed in coconut milk with chilies and shrimp paste.

title: Binagoongan Baboy
subtitle: Pork simmered in shrimp paste with tomatoes
instructions: Sauté garlic and onion; add pork and cook until lightly browned.
Add tomatoes; cook until soft. Stir in shrimp paste and chilies.
Pour water; simmer until pork is tender and sauce reduces. Balance with a pinch of sugar if needed; season with pepper.
description: Pork sautéed in shrimp paste with tomatoes and chilies.

title: Bistek Tagalog
subtitle: Filipino beef steak with calamansi and onions
instructions: Marinate beef in soy, calamansi, pepper 20–30 min.
Sear beef; set aside. Sauté onions; add marinade and water; simmer.
Return beef; season and serve with onions.
description: Beef marinated in calamansi-soy, topped with onions.

title: Bola-bola
subtitle: Filipino meatballs in savory gravy
instructions: Combine ground meat, onion, garlic, carrot, egg, breadcrumbs, salt, and pepper until tacky.
Form 1–1.5 inch balls; chill 15 minutes.
Pan-fry until browned and cooked through. Serve or add to sauce/noodles.
description: Filipino meatballs seasoned with aromatics.

title: Bulalo
subtitle: Beef shank soup with marrow and vegetables
instructions: Cover beef with water; optionally parboil and discard first water to remove impurities.
Refill with fresh water; add onion, garlic, peppercorns; simmer gently 1.5–2 hours until tender.
Add corn and potatoes; cook until tender. Season with salt/fish sauce. Add greens just before serving.
description: Beef shank and marrow soup with vegetables.

title: Bulanglang
subtitle: Vegetable soup with fish or shrimp
instructions: Bring water to boil and add tomatoes and onion.
Add shrimp or fish and cook for 5 minutes.
Add sayote, radish, and eggplant.
Simmer until vegetables are tender.
Season with fish sauce.
Serve hot with rice.
description: A light and healthy Tagalog vegetable soup with shrimp or fish.

title: Calderetang Baka
subtitle: Beef caldereta in tomato sauce
instructions: Brown beef in oil; set aside. Sauté garlic and onion; return beef.
Add tomato sauce and broth; simmer until beef is tender (60–90 minutes).
Add potatoes and carrots; cook until tender. Stir in bell pepper and liver spread (if using). Season to taste.
description: Rich tomato-beef stew; optional liver spread adds depth.

title: Chicken Curry (Filipino)
subtitle: Creamy chicken curry with coconut milk and potatoes
instructions: Sauté garlic, onion, and ginger. Add chicken; cook until lightly browned.
Sprinkle curry powder; stir 30 seconds. Pour coconut milk and water; simmer.
Add potatoes and carrots; cook until tender. Stir in bell peppers; season to taste.
description: Creamy Filipino-style chicken curry with coconut milk and vegetables.

title: Chicken Inasal
subtitle: Ilonggo grilled chicken with calamansi and garlic
ingredients: 2 lbs chicken leg quarters or thighs
instructions: Whisk calamansi, vinegar, garlic, ginger, onion, lemongrass (optional), sugar, salt, and pepper.
Marinate chicken 2–4 hours or overnight.
Mix annatto oil and butter; add a pinch of salt and garlic (optional) for basting.
Grill over medium heat 20–30 minutes, turning and basting, until 74°C/165°F internal.
Rest 5 minutes; serve with spiced vinegar, atchara, and garlic rice.
description: Ilonggo grilled chicken marinated in calamansi, vinegar, and aromatics; basted with annatto oil.

title: Chicken Pastel
subtitle: Creamy chicken stew with mushrooms and sausages
instructions: Sauté garlic and onion; add chicken and cook until no longer pink.
Add mushrooms and sausages; sauté briefly.
Pour broth and milk/cream; simmer.
Add carrot, peas (and potatoes if using); cook until tender and sauce is creamy. Season to taste.
description: Creamy chicken stew with mushrooms and sausages.

title: Chopsuey
subtitle: Stir-fried vegetables with meat and quail eggs
instructions: Sauté garlic and onion; add meat/shrimp if using and cook until just done.
Add hard vegetables (carrots, sayote) then stock and sauces; simmer briefly.
Stir in cabbage and florets; add cornstarch slurry to thicken.
Toss in quail eggs; season to taste and serve.
description: Stir-fry of mixed vegetables with light savory sauce.

title: Crispy Pata
subtitle: Deep-fried pork knuckles with dipping sauce
ingredients: 1/4 cup salt (for simmering/brine), plus extra to season
Pinch of sugar and black pepper
instructions: Simmer pork leg with salt, garlic, onion, peppercorns, bay leaves, and vinegar until tender.
Drain, dry thoroughly, and chill uncovered 4 hours or overnight to dry the skin.
Deep-fry at 175–180°C until blistered and crisp; rest 10 minutes.
Serve with soy–vinegar–calamansi dipping sauce with onion and garlic.
description: Deep-fried pork leg with shatteringly crisp skin and juicy meat.

title: Daing na Bangus
subtitle: Marinated milkfish fried until crisp
instructions: Combine vinegar, garlic, salt, and pepper. Marinate bangus 8–12 hours (refrigerated).
Drain and pat dry. Pan-fry skin-side down first until crisp; flip and cook the other side.
Serve with garlic rice and spiced vinegar.
description: Milkfish marinated in vinegar, garlic, and pepper, then fried until crisp.

title: Dinakdakan
subtitle: Ilocano grilled pork salad with onions and mayo
instructions: Boil pork parts in salted water until tender; drain and grill/sear for smoky flavor.
Chop into small pieces. Toss with onions, calamansi juice, mayo (or liver), garlic (optional), and chilies.
Season to taste; serve warm.
description: Grilled/boiled pork salad with creamy-citrus dressing.

title: Dinuguan
subtitle: Rich and savory pork blood stew
instructions: Sauté garlic and onion; add pork and cook until lightly browned.
Pour water/broth and simmer until tender.
Lower heat; stir in pork blood gradually. Add vinegar and chili; simmer gently, stirring, until thick. Season to taste.
description: Savory, tangy pork blood stew.

title: Embutido
subtitle: Filipino-style steamed meatloaf with carrots and raisins
instructions: Mix pork, onion, garlic, carrot, relish, raisins, breadcrumbs, eggs, salt, and pepper until tacky.
Spread on foil, arrange egg and hotdogs; roll and seal tightly.
Steam 50–60 minutes. Cool, slice, and pan-fry if desired.
description: Filipino-style steamed meatloaf with sweet-savory notes.

title: Empanadang Manok
subtitle: Filipino chicken empanadas
instructions: Filling: sauté garlic and onion; add chicken, potato, carrot; pour broth and simmer until tender. Stir in peas; season; cool.
Dough: mix flour and salt; cut in butter until sandy; add cold water to bring together. Chill 20–30 minutes.
Assemble: roll dough, cut rounds, add filling, fold and crimp. Brush with egg wash. Bake at 200°C (400°F) 20–25 minutes until golden.
description: Savory chicken empanadas with flaky pastry.

title: Ensaladang Labanos at Kamatis
subtitle: Traditional Bulacan radish and tomato salad
instructions: Sprinkle salt over julienned radish and let sit for 10 minutes.
Rinse radish and squeeze out excess water.
Arrange radish, tomatoes, and onions in a serving bowl.
Mix calamansi juice, oil, minced garlic, salt, and pepper for dressing.
Pour dressing over vegetables and toss gently.
Top with sliced hard-boiled egg if desired.
Chill for 10 minutes before serving.
Serve as a refreshing side dish.
description: A refreshing and zesty salad that highlights the crisp texture of fresh radish paired with ripe tomatoes, dressed in a tangy calamansi vinaigrette.

title: Escabecheng Isda
subtitle: Sweet and sour fish with peppers and carrots
instructions: Season fish; fry until crisp. Set on a platter.
Sauce: sauté garlic and onion; add carrot/bell pepper.
Add water, vinegar, ketchup, and sugar; simmer. Thicken with cornstarch slurry; season.
Pour over fried fish and serve.
description: Fried fish topped with sweet-and-sour vegetable sauce.

title: Ginataang Alimasag
subtitle: Crab simmered in coconut milk
instructions: Sauté garlic, onion, and ginger.
Add crabs; toss. Pour coconut milk; add chilies. Simmer until crabs are cooked.
Stir in coconut cream (if using); season to taste.
description: Crabs simmered in rich coconut milk with aromatics.

title: Ginataang Gulay
subtitle: Vegetables cooked in coconut milk
ingredients: Fish sauce or salt to taste
instructions: Sauté garlic and onion until fragrant.
Add eggplant, carrot, and sayote.
Pour in coconut milk and bring to simmer.
Add chili peppers and cook until vegetables are tender.
Season with fish sauce or salt.
Serve with steamed rice.
description: A creamy vegetable dish with a hint of spice, cooked in coconut milk.

title: Ginataang Hipon
subtitle: Shrimp cooked in coconut milk
instructions: Sauté garlic, onion, and ginger.
Add shrimp; pour coconut milk; add chilies; simmer until pink.
Add coconut cream (if using); season.
description: Shrimp in creamy coconut sauce with ginger and chilies.

title: Ginataang Kalabasa at Sitaw
subtitle: Squash and long beans in coconut milk
instructions: Sauté garlic and onion. Add squash; stir 1–2 minutes.
Pour coconut milk; simmer until nearly tender.
Add sitaw (and chilies); cook until vegetables are done. Season to taste.
description: Comforting coconut stew with squash and long beans.

title: Ginataang Langka
subtitle: Young jackfruit stewed in coconut milk
instructions: Sauté garlic, onion, and ginger.
Add jackfruit; toss, then pour coconut milk.
Simmer until tender; add chilies; season to taste.
description: Young jackfruit stewed in coconut milk with ginger and chilies.

title: Ginisang Ampalaya
subtitle: Sautéed bitter melon with egg and tomatoes
instructions: Sauté garlic and onion (add tomatoes if using) until soft.
Add ampalaya; cook until just tender. Season and serve.
description: Everyday sautéed vegetable dish with garlic and onions.

title: Ginisang Gulay
subtitle: Traditional Bulacan mixed vegetable stir-fry
instructions: Heat oil in a large pan or wok.
Sauté garlic, ginger, and onions until aromatic.
Add tomatoes and cook until soft.
Add potatoes first and cook for 5 minutes.
Add carrots and cook for another 3 minutes.
Add eggplant, chayote, and radish.
Stir-fry for 8-10 minutes until vegetables are tender-crisp.
Season with salt and pepper.
Serve hot with steamed rice.
description: A healthy and colorful vegetable medley that showcases the fresh produce of Bulacan, perfect as a main dish or side dish.

title: Ginisang Itlog at Kamatis
subtitle: Simple Filipino-style scrambled eggs
instructions: Heat oil in a pan, sauté garlic and onions until fragrant.
Add tomatoes and cook until soft and mushy.
Pour in beaten eggs and let sit for 30 seconds.
Gently scramble eggs with tomato mixture.
Season with salt and pepper.
Cook until eggs are set but still creamy.
Serve hot with rice and calamansi.
description: A simple and delicious egg dish that combines the sweetness of tomatoes with fluffy scrambled eggs, perfect for any meal.

title: Ginisang Labanos
subtitle: Sautéed radish with pork
instructions: Heat oil in a pan over medium heat.
Sauté garlic, onion, ginger, and tomatoes until fragrant and soft.
Add pork and cook until lightly browned and no longer pink.
Add fish sauce and pepper, stir well and let simmer for 2 minutes.
Add sliced radish and mix to combine.
Pour in water, cover, and let it simmer for 5–7 minutes or until radish is tender.
Taste and adjust with salt if needed.
Serve hot with steamed rice.
description: A hearty vegetable dish featuring tender radish sautéed with garlic, tomatoes, and savory pork.

title: Ginisang Langka
subtitle: Hearty and flavorful young jackfruit dish
ingredients: 1 cup coconut milk (optional, for creamier version)
instructions: Heat oil in a pan, sauté garlic, onion, and tomato until softened.
Add shredded young jackfruit and stir-fry for a few minutes.
Pour in fish sauce (if using) and mix well.
Add a little water (or coconut milk for creamier flavor) and simmer until jackfruit is tender.
Season with salt and pepper to taste.
Serve hot with rice.
description: A savory Filipino dish made with young jackfruit, sautéed with aromatics, and optionally cooked in coconut milk for a richer taste.

title: Ginisang Pechay
subtitle: Sautéed bok choy with garlic and onions
instructions: Sauté garlic and onion (add tomatoes if using) until soft.
Add pechay/bok choy; cook until just tender. Season and serve.
description: Everyday sautéed vegetable dish with garlic and onions.

title: Ginisang Puso ng Saging
subtitle: Banana blossom sautéed with aromatics and coconut milk
instructions: Sauté garlic and onion (add tomatoes if using) until soft.
Add banana blossom; cook until just tender. Season and serve.
description: Everyday sautéed vegetable dish with garlic and onions.

title: Ginisang Repolyo
subtitle: Sautéed cabbage with carrots and ground pork
instructions: Sauté garlic and onion (add tomatoes if using) until soft.
Add cabbage; cook until just tender. Season and serve.
description: Everyday sautéed vegetable dish with garlic and onions.

title: Ginisang Sayote
subtitle: Sautéed chayote with eggs
instructions: Heat oil in a pan, sauté garlic, ginger, and onions.
Add tomatoes and cook until soft.
Add sliced chayote and stir-fry for 8-10 minutes.
Season with salt and pepper.
Push vegetables to one side of the pan.
Pour beaten eggs and scramble.
Mix eggs with vegetables and cook for 2 more minutes.
Serve hot with steamed rice.
description: A simple and healthy vegetable dish featuring tender chayote sautéed with aromatics and finished with scrambled eggs.

title: Ginisang Sitaw
subtitle: Sautéed string beans with garlic and tomatoes
instructions: Sauté garlic and onion (add tomatoes if using) until soft.
Add string beans; cook until just tender. Season and serve.
description: Everyday sautéed vegetable dish with garlic and onions.

title: Ginisang Togue
subtitle: Sautéed mung bean sprouts with tofu and pork
instructions: Sauté garlic and onion (add tomatoes if using) until soft.
Add mung bean sprouts; cook until just tender. Season and serve.
description: Everyday sautéed vegetable dish with garlic and onions.

title: Gising-Gising
subtitle: Spicy green beans in coconut milk
ingredients: 1 tbsp shrimp paste or fish sauce
instructions: Sauté garlic and onion; add pork if using and cook until lightly browned.
Stir in chopped beans and chilies. Pour coconut milk and simmer until beans are tender-crisp.
Season with shrimp paste/fish sauce and pepper.
description: Spicy coconut milk dish of chopped beans.

title: Goto
subtitle: Beef tripe congee with ginger and garlic
ingredients: 300 g beef tripe and/or ox tripe (pre-boiled, sliced)
Fish sauce and pepper to taste
Calamansi and toasted garlic for serving
instructions: Sauté ginger, garlic, and onion in oil. Add rice; stir 1 minute.
Pour water/broth; simmer, stirring occasionally, until porridge is thick.
Add tripe; simmer until tender. Season with fish sauce and pepper. Serve with calamansi and toasted garlic.
description: Ginger-forward rice porridge with tripe.

title: Hamon Bulakenya
subtitle: One of the food served during the Liberation of Bulacan Province
instructions: Prick all sides of the meat very well.
Mix sugar, salt and prague powder then wipe it unto the meat.
Place in a covered container and refrigerate it for 3 days.
After 3 days wash the meat and have it boiled in pineapple juice, beer, sugar mixture until tender.
Place the meat in a tray and sprinkle top with extra sugar.
Then pat with hot iron or siense to caramelize the sugar.
Cut into serving pieces.
description: A traditional Bulacan heritage recipe served during the Liberation of Bulacan Province, featuring cured pork with a caramelized sugar coating.

title: Inihaw na Baboy
subtitle: Filipino pork barbecue skewers
ingredients: 1 kg pork shoulder or liempo (sliced into 1/2-inch thick pieces)
instructions: In a bowl, whisk calamansi juice, soy sauce, garlic, brown sugar, pepper, and a pinch of salt.
Add pork and massage marinade. Cover and marinate 1–3 hours (overnight best).
Preheat grill to medium-high. Shake off excess marinade; reserve the rest for basting.
Grill pork 3–4 minutes per side, basting with reserved marinade mixed with oil (and banana ketchup if using) until lightly charred and cooked through.
Rest 5 minutes. Slice and serve with red onion and a dipping sauce of calamansi and soy.
description: A home-style Filipino dish: Inihaw na Baboy.

title: Inihaw na Bangus
subtitle: Grilled milkfish stuffed with tomatoes and onions
instructions: In a bowl, combine tomatoes, red onion, ginger, and garlic. Season with salt and pepper.
Season fish with salt and pepper, drizzle with calamansi juice and a little oil.
Stuff the fish cavity with the tomato–onion mixture. Wrap in banana leaf and/or foil to secure.
Grill over medium heat 8–10 minutes per side until fish is cooked through and flakes easily.
Unwrap and serve hot with calamansi–soy dip.
description: A home-style Filipino dish: Inihaw na Bangus.

title: Inihaw na Liempo
subtitle: Grilled pork belly with calamansi-soy marinade
ingredients: 1 kg pork belly (liempo), slab or thick slices
instructions: Combine calamansi juice, soy sauce, garlic, sugar, pepper, and fish sauce (if using).
Marinate liempo 3–8 hours, chilled. Bring to room temp 20 minutes before grilling.
Preheat grill to medium. Pat meat dry. Reserve marinade for basting.
Grill 5–7 minutes per side, basting with marinade mixed with oil (and ketchup if using) until caramelized and cooked through.
Rest 10 minutes. Slice and serve with calamansi–soy dip.
description: A home-style Filipino dish: Inihaw na Liempo.

title: Inihaw na Manok
subtitle: Filipino grilled chicken with garlic marinade
ingredients: 1.2 kg chicken leg quarters or breast fillets
instructions: Whisk calamansi, soy sauce, garlic, ginger, sugar, and pepper. Add chicken and coat well.
Marinate 2–6 hours. Preheat grill to medium.
Grill chicken skin-side down 6–8 minutes, then flip. Baste with remaining marinade mixed with oil (and ketchup if using).
Continue grilling until juices run clear and internal temp reaches 74°C (165°F).
Rest 5 minutes. Serve with calamansi and sliced red onion.
description: A home-style Filipino dish: Inihaw na Manok.

title: Inihaw na Pusit
subtitle: Grilled stuffed squid with tomatoes and onions
instructions: Whisk calamansi juice, soy sauce, garlic, ginger, oil, salt, and pepper. Toss squid and marinate 15–30 minutes.
Mix tomatoes and red onion; season lightly. Stuff squid bodies with the mixture and secure openings with toothpicks.
Preheat grill to high. Grill squid 1–2 minutes per side just until opaque and lightly charred (avoid overcooking).
Serve immediately with extra calamansi on the side.
description: A home-style Filipino dish: Inihaw na Pusit.

title: Kadyos, Baboy, Langka (KBL)
subtitle: Ilonggo soup with pigeon peas, pork, and jackfruit
ingredients: 1 cup kadyos (pigeon peas), pre-soaked or canned
instructions: Combine pork, kadyos, ginger, onion, and water; simmer until pork is tender.
Add jackfruit and batwan/kamias; simmer until jackfruit is soft.
Season with salt and pepper.
description: Hearty Ilonggo soup of peas, pork, and jackfruit with a sour note.

title: Kansi
subtitle: Ilonggo beef shank soup with sour broth
instructions: Simmer beef shank with onion and ginger until tender.
Add batwan/kamias for sourness; season with salt/fish sauce and pepper.
Serve hot.
description: Bacolod-style sour beef shank soup.

title: Kare-Kare
subtitle: Filipino oxtail stew with peanut sauce
instructions: Boil oxtail and tripe in water for 2 hours until tender.
Reserve the broth and set meat aside.
Sauté garlic and onions in annatto oil.
Add ground peanuts and rice flour, mix well.
Gradually add reserved broth while stirring.
Return meat to the pot and simmer for 15 minutes.
Add vegetables and cook until tender.
Season with salt.
Serve hot with bagoong and steamed rice.
description: A rich and creamy Filipino stew featuring oxtail and vegetables in a thick peanut sauce, traditionally served with bagoong.

title: Kinilaw na Tuna
subtitle: Filipino-style fish ceviche with calamansi and ginger
instructions: Rinse tuna quickly; drain well. Toss with ginger, onion, and chilies.
Pour vinegar and calamansi; season with salt and pepper. Marinate 10–15 minutes; serve immediately.
description: Fresh tuna cured in vinegar/calamansi with ginger and onions.

title: La Paz Batchoy
subtitle: Iloilo noodle soup with pork and crushed chicharron
ingredients: 6 cloves garlic (minced, plus extra for topping)
instructions: Sauté garlic and onion; add pork and bones; pour broth and simmer for flavor.
Season to taste. Blanch noodles in boiling broth.
Assemble bowls; top with pork, broth, chicharrón, spring onions, and toasted garlic (and egg).
description: Rich noodle soup with porky broth and toppings.

title: Laing
subtitle: Taro leaves stewed in coconut milk and chilies
instructions: Simmer coconut milk with onion, garlic, ginger, and chilies for 5 minutes.
Add taro leaves (do not stir initially); simmer gently until tender and most liquid is absorbed.
Stir in coconut cream if using; season to taste.
description: Dried taro leaves stewed in coconut milk with chilies.

title: Lechon Kawali
subtitle: Crispy pan-fried pork belly
instructions: Simmer pork belly with aromatics until tender. Drain and dry completely.
Chill uncovered to dry the skin (2–4 hours).
Deep-fry carefully at 175–180°C until skin is blistered and crisp. Rest and chop; serve with sawsawan.
description: Crispy pan-fried pork belly, tender inside and crunchy outside.

title: Lomi
subtitle: Thick egg noodle soup with meat and vegetables
instructions: Sauté garlic and onion; add meat. Pour broth and bring to a boil.
Add noodles and carrot; cook until tender. Thicken with cornstarch slurry.
Drizzle in beaten egg while stirring; season to taste.
description: Hearty thick egg noodle soup with egg-drop.

title: Lumpiang Shanghai
subtitle: Crispy pork spring rolls with carrots
instructions: Mix pork, carrot, onion, garlic, egg, breadcrumbs, salt, and pepper.
Wrap in lumpia wrappers; seal with water. Fry until golden and crisp.
description: Crispy pork spring rolls with carrots.

title: Lumpiang Togue
subtitle: Vegetable spring rolls with bean sprouts
ingredients: 1 tbsp soy sauce or fish sauce
instructions: Sauté garlic and onion; add vegetables; season and cook briefly until just wilted. Cool.
Wrap in lumpia wrappers; fry until golden.
description: Vegetable lumpia packed with bean sprouts.

title: Mechado
subtitle: Soy-tomato braised beef with potatoes
instructions: Brown beef; sauté garlic and onion. Add tomato sauce, soy, and broth; simmer until tender.
Add potatoes (and bell pepper); cook until tender. Season to taste.
description: Soy-tomato braised beef with potatoes.

title: Menudo
subtitle: Pork and liver stew with potatoes and carrots
instructions: Sauté garlic and onion; add pork and cook until no longer pink.
Pour tomato sauce and broth; simmer until tender.
Add potatoes, carrots, and peas. Stir in liver last; cook 3–5 minutes. Season.
description: Pork and liver stew with potatoes, carrots, and peas.

title: Molo Soup (Pancit Molo)
subtitle: Ilonggo wonton soup with aromatics
instructions: Mix filling; wrap into wontons.
Sauté garlic and onion; pour broth and bring to a boil.
Drop in wontons; cook until wrappers are tender. Garnish and serve.
description: Pancit Molo—wonton soup with pork-shrimp filling.

title: Monggo Guisado (Ginisang Munggo)
subtitle: Mung bean stew with pork and chicharron
instructions: Boil mung beans until tender.
Sauté garlic, onion, and tomatoes; add pork/shrimp if using.
Combine with cooked beans; season to taste. Stir in leaves just before serving.
description: Comforting mung bean stew; often topped with chicharrón.

title: Nilagang Baboy
subtitle: Pork soup with potatoes and vegetables
instructions: Simmer pork with onion until tender; skim impurities.
Add potatoes (and corn if using); cook until tender.
Season; add greens just before serving.
description: Clear pork soup with potatoes and vegetables.

title: Nilagang Baka
subtitle: Filipino beef soup with vegetables
ingredients: 1 kg beef brisket or short ribs
instructions: Place beef in a large pot with water, bring to a boil.
Add ginger, garlic, and onions.
Simmer for 1.5 hours until beef is tender.
Add potatoes and carrots, cook for 15 minutes.
Add radish and cook for 10 more minutes.
Season with salt, pepper, and fish sauce.
Serve hot with steamed rice and calamansi.
description: A hearty Filipino beef soup with tender vegetables in a clear, flavorful broth that's perfect for family meals.

title: Paksiw na Isda
subtitle: Fish stewed in vinegar and vegetables
instructions: Layer fish, tomatoes, eggplant, onion, and garlic in a pot.
Pour vinegar and water over the ingredients.
Season with salt and pepper.
Cover and simmer on low heat for 20 minutes until fish is cooked.
Serve hot with steamed rice.
description: A tangy Filipino fish dish simmered in vinegar, aromatics, and vegetables.

title: Pancit Bihon
subtitle: Stir-fried rice noodles with chicken and vegetables
instructions: Sauté garlic and onion; add meat and stock.
Add soaked bihon; toss until noodles absorb liquid.
Stir in carrots and cabbage; season. Serve with calamansi.
description: Rice noodles stir-fried with meat and vegetables.

title: Pancit Canton
subtitle: Stir-fried egg noodles with meat and vegetables
instructions: Sauté aromatics; add meat/seafood. Pour stock and sauces.
Add noodles; toss as it absorbs. Add vegetables; season and serve with calamansi.
description: Egg noodles tossed with meat, vegetables, and savory sauce.

title: Pancit Habhab
subtitle: Lucban miki noodles served on banana leaf
instructions: Sauté garlic and onion; add noodles with a splash of water/stock.
Season with soy and vinegar. Toss in vegetables; cook until just tender.
description: Lucban-style noodles seasoned with vinegar; traditionally eaten on banana leaf.

title: Pancit Malabon
subtitle: Seafood noodle dish with annatto sauce
instructions: Sauce: sauté garlic and onion in annatto oil; add shrimp broth and fish sauce; thicken with cornstarch slurry.
Cook noodles per package; toss with sauce.
Top with eggs, shrimp, chicharrón, green onions, and calamansi.
description: Seafood noodle dish with annatto sauce (Malabon).

title: Pancit Palabok
subtitle: Rice noodles with shrimp sauce and toppings
instructions: Sauce: sauté garlic and onion in annatto oil; add shrimp broth and fish sauce; thicken with cornstarch slurry.
Cook noodles per package; toss with sauce.
Top with eggs, shrimp, chicharrón, green onions, and calamansi.
description: Rice noodles with rich shrimp sauce and toppings (Palabok).

title: Pata Tim
subtitle: Braised pork hock in sweet soy sauce
instructions: Sauté garlic and onion; add pork hock and sear.
Pour soy sauce, sugar, oyster sauce, water, and star anise; simmer gently until tender (1.5–2.5 hours).
Add pechay; cook 1–2 minutes. Reduce sauce to glaze; serve.
description: Chinese-Filipino braised pork hock in sweet soy with star anise.

title: Pinakbet
subtitle: Ilocano vegetable stew with eggplant and bitter melon
instructions: Sauté garlic, onion, and tomatoes. Add hard veggies (squash) first; cook a few minutes.
Add remaining vegetables and bagoong; cover and cook until just tender. Season with pepper.
description: Ilocano vegetable stew flavored with bagoong.

title: Pinangat na Isda
subtitle: Fish simmered in tomatoes and sour broth
ingredients: 1/4 cup vinegar or a few kamias
instructions: Layer tomatoes, onion, and ginger in a pot; place fish on top.
Add vinegar and water; season lightly. Cover and simmer gently until fish is cooked.
Adjust seasoning and serve.
description: Fish gently simmered in tomatoes, ginger, and souring agent.

title: Pininyahang Manok
subtitle: Chicken braised with pineapple and milk
ingredients: 1 cup evaporated milk or coconut milk
instructions: Sauté garlic and onion; add chicken and cook until lightly browned.
Pour in pineapple juice and milk; simmer until chicken is tender.
Add pineapple chunks and bell pepper; season and cook 2–3 minutes more.
description: Chicken stewed with pineapple and milk for a sweet-creamy sauce.

title: Pochero
subtitle: Beef stew with tomato, saba bananas, and vegetables
instructions: Brown beef; sauté garlic and onion. Add tomato sauce and broth; simmer until tender.
Add potatoes and bananas; cook until tender. Add greens; season and serve.
description: Beef stew with tomato, saba bananas, and vegetables.

title: Poqui Poqui
subtitle: Traditional Bulacan eggplant and egg dish
instructions: Roast eggplants over open flame until skin is charred and flesh is soft.
Peel off charred skin and mash the eggplant flesh.
Heat oil in pan, sauté garlic and onions until fragrant.
Add tomatoes and cook until soft.
Add mashed eggplant and mix well.
Pour beaten eggs and scramble together.
Season with salt and pepper.
Serve hot with steamed rice and calamansi on the side.
description: A beloved Bulacan comfort food that combines roasted eggplant with scrambled eggs, creating a smoky and satisfying dish perfect for any meal.

title: Pork Asado
subtitle: Chinese-Filipino style pork asado
instructions: Combine soy, sugar, calamansi, water, garlic, and onion; add pork and simmer gently until tender.
Remove pork and slice; reduce sauce to glaze. Return slices to coat; serve.
description: Sweet-savory braised pork, sliced and sauced.

title: Rellenong Talong
subtitle: Stuffed eggplant
instructions: Grill eggplants until tender but keep shape intact.
Carefully make a slit and scoop out flesh, keeping skin whole.
Heat oil and sauté garlic, onion, and tomatoes.
Add eggplant flesh and cook until mushy.
Add 2 beaten eggs and scramble mixture.
Season with salt and pepper, let cool.
Stuff eggplant shells with the mixture.
Dip stuffed eggplants in remaining beaten egg.
Pan-fry until golden brown on all sides.
Serve hot with calamansi and rice.
description: An elegant Bulacan dish where eggplants are hollowed out and stuffed with a savory egg mixture, then fried to perfection.

title: Sardinas na may Itlog at Kamatis
subtitle: Canned sardines sautéed with tomato and egg
instructions: Sauté garlic, onion, and tomatoes until soft.
Add sardines and simmer for 5 minutes.
Push mixture to one side and add beaten eggs.
Scramble then mix everything together.
Serve hot with calamansi and rice.
description: A budget-friendly Filipino ulam made with canned sardines, tomato, and eggs.

title: Sarsiadong Isda
subtitle: Fried fish with tomato-egg sauce
ingredients: 1 whole fish (tilapia, bangus, or galunggong), cleaned and scored
instructions: Season fish with salt and pepper. Fry until crisp and cooked; set aside.
Sauté garlic and onion; add tomatoes and cook until soft.
Pour in water/broth; season with fish sauce and pepper; simmer briefly.
Lower heat; drizzle in beaten eggs while stirring to create ribbons.
Pour sauce over fried fish; serve with rice and calamansi.
description: Crispy fried fish topped with a savory tomato-onion sauce finished with fluffy egg ribbons.

title: Sinampalukang Manok
subtitle: Bulacan-style tamarind chicken soup
instructions: Heat oil in a large pot.
Sauté garlic, ginger, onion, and tomatoes.
Add chicken pieces and brown lightly.
Pour water and bring to a boil.
Simmer for 30 minutes until chicken is tender.
Add potatoes and cook for 10 minutes.
Add radish and cook for 5 more minutes.
Season with salt, pepper, and fish sauce.
Serve hot with steamed rice.
description: A comforting and sour soup that's a Bulacan favorite, combining tender chicken with fresh vegetables in a flavorful tamarind-based broth.

title: Sinigang na Hipon
subtitle: Filipino shrimp tamarind soup
instructions: Boil water in a large pot and add tamarind soup mix.
Add tomatoes and onions, simmer for 5 minutes.
Add taro and cook for 10 minutes until tender.
Add shrimp and cook for 3-4 minutes until pink.
Add okra and green chili, cook for 3 minutes.
Add kangkong and cook for 2 minutes until wilted.
Season with fish sauce, salt, and pepper.
Serve hot with steamed rice.
description: A tangy and savory Filipino soup featuring fresh shrimp and vegetables in a flavorful tamarind broth that's both comforting and refreshing.

title: Sisig
subtitle: Sizzling pork sisig
instructions: Boil pork belly until tender, then chop finely.
Sauté garlic, onion, and ginger until fragrant.
Add chopped pork and cook until crispy.
Add tomatoes and cook until softened.
Season with calamansi juice and pepper.
Top with raw egg and mayonnaise before serving.
Serve hot on sizzling plate.
description: A traditional Filipino sizzling pork sisig, featuring crispy pork belly with authentic flavors and cooking techniques passed down through generations.

title: Tinolang Isda
subtitle: Fish soup with ginger and vegetables
ingredients: 1/2 kilo fish (tilapia or bangus, cut into pieces)
instructions: Bring water to boil with ginger and onion.
Add fish and cook for 10 minutes.
Add sayote and simmer until tender.
Season with fish sauce.
Add leafy greens and cook for 2 minutes.
Serve hot with rice.
description: A light fish soup flavored with ginger and vegetables, perfect with rice.

title: Tinolang Manok
subtitle: Filipino chicken ginger soup
instructions: Heat oil in a pot, sauté ginger, garlic, and onions.
Add chicken pieces and cook until lightly browned.
Pour water and bring to a boil.
Simmer for 25 minutes until chicken is tender.
Add chayote and cook for 10 more minutes.
Season with fish sauce, salt, and pepper.
Serve hot with steamed rice.
description: A comforting Filipino soup featuring chicken and vegetables in a clear, ginger-infused broth that's perfect for cold weather.

title: Beef Tapa
subtitle: Marinated and pan-fried beef for tapsilog
ingredients: 700 g beef sirloin or round (thin slices)
instructions: In a bowl, combine soy sauce, vinegar/calamansi, garlic, sugar, and pepper. Add beef; marinate 2–8 hours (chilled).
Drain; pat beef dry. Heat oil in a skillet over medium-high.
Pan-fry beef in batches until just cooked and slightly caramelized.
Serve with garlic fried rice and fried egg for tapsilog.
description: Thinly sliced beef marinated in soy, vinegar/calamansi, garlic, and a touch of sugar, then pan-fried until savory-sweet and slightly caramelized.

title: Pork Giniling
subtitle: Ground pork in tomato sauce with potatoes, carrots, and raisins
ingredients: 2 medium tomatoes (chopped) or 1 cup tomato sauce
2 tbsp soy sauce or fish sauce
instructions: Heat oil in a pan; sauté garlic and onion until soft.
Add ground pork; cook until lightly browned and crumbled.
Stir in tomatoes or tomato sauce; add water/broth and soy/fish sauce. Simmer 10 minutes.
Add potatoes, carrots, and raisins; cook until vegetables are tender.
Stir in green peas; season with pepper and adjust salt. Simmer 2 minutes more.
description: A homey tomato-based ground pork stew with potatoes, carrots, and a hint of sweetness from raisins—perfect with steamed rice.

title: Tortang Talong
subtitle: Bulacan-style eggplant omelet
instructions: Grill eggplants until skin is charred and flesh is tender.
Carefully peel off skin, keeping the stem intact.
Gently flatten the eggplant with a fork.
Beat eggs with salt and pepper.
Dip each eggplant in beaten egg mixture.
Pan-fry until golden brown on both sides.
Serve hot with rice and calamansi dipping sauce.
description: A classic Filipino dish popular in Bulacan, featuring grilled eggplant coated in egg and pan-fried to golden perfection.

title: Humba (Pork Humba)
subtitle: Visayan sweet-savory braised pork with banana blossoms and black beans
instructions: Sear pork in a little oil until lightly browned; push to the sides. Sauté garlic and onion until fragrant.
Add soy sauce, vinegar, sugar, pineapple juice (if using), tausi, bay leaves, and star anise. Pour in water to cover.
Bring to a boil, then simmer uncovered until pork is tender and sauce reduces.
Stir in banana blossoms in the last 10 minutes; season with pepper and adjust sweetness/saltiness to taste.
description: A Visayan-style braise akin to adobo but sweeter and richer, featuring tausi and banana blossoms for depth and aroma.

title: Ukoy na Labanos
subtitle: Bulacan-style radish fritters
ingredients: Calamansi and soy sauce for dipping
instructions: Mix flour with water to make a batter.
Add beaten eggs, garlic, and onion to batter.
Season with salt and pepper.
Mix in julienned radish and carrot.
Heat oil for deep frying.
Drop spoonfuls of mixture into hot oil.
Fry until golden brown and crispy.
Drain on paper towels.
Serve hot with calamansi-soy sauce dipping sauce.
description: A crispy and flavorful fritter dish popular in Bulacan, featuring fresh radish and vegetables bound in a light, crispy batter.
